Award.AwardTitle: Preparation of Volatile Heterometallic Precursors for the Synthesis of Mixed-Metal Oxides, Oxyfluorides, Fluorides, and Silicates with Multiferroic Properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Dikarev of the Department of Chemistry at University at Albany will broadly explore heterometallic alpha-diketonates as single-source precursors for the synthesis of mixed-metal materials. Specific combinations of heavy metals (Ba, Sn, Pb, Bi, RE) with 3d transition metals (Ti/Ni) that result in materials with valuable multiferroic properties will be targeted. This work will focus on volatile single-source precursors that can be used in MOCVD preparation of thin films, deposition on solid support, growth of single crystals, and formation of nanoparticles. It will be demonstrated that heterometallic diketonates are universal precursors that can be explored for the preparation of a wide array of multiferroic materials: oxides, oxyfluorides, fluorides, and silicates. The broader impacts involve an enhancement of the educational and research experiences of graduate and undergraduate students and participation in university wide and community initiatives, such as continuing development of forensic chemistry program.

This work will lead to more efficient preparation of new class of multifunctional materials called multiferroics. Successful development of the methodology will have an impact on other areas of materials chemistry in which the synthesis of mixed-metal compounds is needed, such as high-temperature superconductors, rechargeable battery electrodes, and chemical sensors. In addition, this project will provide excellent training of students, from pre-undergraduate to graduate, including those from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research program was focused on preparation of heterometallic (main group–transition metal/lanthanide) compounds that can be used as volatile precursors for the low-temperature synthesis of energy-related oxide, fluoride, silicate, and phosphate materials. During the funding period, the synthetic effort was centered at the following important features of an industrially-attractive single-source precursor: (i) Preparation of compounds that contain all the necessary elements in a proper ratio and exhibit a clean, low-temperature decomposition leading to the target material; (ii) Isolation of precursors on a large scale, with high yield, through one-pot synthesis from commercially/readily available reagents; (iii) Retention of heterometallic structure in solution and in the gas phase to ensure that compounds act as true single-source rather than multi-source (a mixture of homometallic components) precursors; (iv) Influence of decomposition conditions such as atmosphere (oxygen, air, nitrogen, argon), temperature, pressure, and annealing time on the formation of target materials; (v) Search for the ligands that assist in achieving the lowest precursor decomposition temperature, allowing an efficient preparation of materials in a form of nanosized particles. The results were described in 14 research publications (3 more are submitted), two graduate theses, and 53 presentations at the national and international meetings (22 by students, including 6 abroad). Two of those publications were featured in JACS Spotlight and appear on the journal cover. A total of eight graduate and three undergraduate students were involved in this research. Four PhD students have defended their research proposals on the subject of this project, two of those have graduated and two are nearing the graduation. Four of the project participants have found jobs in academia and chemical industry. The PI was an AMADEUS Professor at the University of Bordeaux, France in 2016 while working on magnetic characterization of compounds from this project.

The results obtained in the course of this project were an integral part of two successful NSF Major Research Instrumentation proposals for acquisition of dual-source X-ray single crystal diffractometer and ambient ionization mass spectrometer for research and teaching. Based on the work on this project, two PI's proposals to request a beamtime at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory and Argonne National Laboratory for single crystal neutron and resonant diffraction experiments, respectively, have been funded. The PI received a collaborative grant from the CRDF Global that supports the use of heterometallic precursors prepared in this project for surface coating of Li-rich NMC cathode materials. Several new compounds obtained by project participants have been introduced into X-ray Crystallography and Advanced Synthesis courses at UAlbany.

Supplement funding to this project for international collaboration allowed our group to establish a new joint research project with the world-renowned Electrochemistry Division at the Moscow State University that provides complex electrochemical investigation of the materials from around the world. The international research component, that was pivotal for proposed activities, resulted in visits by the PI and four of his graduate students to the partner laboratory abroad. UAlbany students participating in the project gained a valuable experience in international collaboration. Instead of sending the samples to counterpart lab for complete workout, students were trained in electrochemistry including theory, sample preparation, measurements, and interpretation of the results. The participants have also got acquainted with high-resolution electron microscopy technique, EDX/WDX analysis, and in-situ powder X-ray diffraction data collection. Such training is not currently offered at UAlbany, however the corresponding instrumentation will become available at the new university ETEK Building scheduled to open in 2018. Participating students had an opportunity to report their results at two major international conferences as well as to deliver research presentations at the bilateral meeting ‘Inorganic Chemistry towards Materials for Energy’ in 2015. Three papers have been published and three joint manuscripts are being submitted or currently under preparation by team members.
